headline.main: New Cancer Threat Lurks Long After Cure
headline.print_headline: Essay: New Cancer Threat Lurks Long After Cure

docs.abstract: Secondary cancers now make up the sixth-most-common group of malignancies, in part because more survivors are living longer.
docs.snippet: Secondary cancers now make up the sixth-most-common group of malignancies, in part because more survivors are living longer.

docs.lead_paragraph: The slogans and scare stories have taken over the discussion. The Affordable Care Act is humane, fiscally viable and Democrats should be out there defending it.
docs.abstract: Bill Keller Op-Ed column contends that the Affordable Care Act is a humane and fiscally viable program, and that slogans and scare tactics have hijacked the national debate about its merits; argues that Democrats should become more confrontational in defending the law, and should no longer allow Republicans to frame it in the public eye.
docs.snippet: The slogans and scare stories have taken over the discussion. The Affordable Care Act is humane, fiscally viable and Democrats should be out there defending it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Representatives of the two sides met again on Saturday but failed to reach an agreement. The dispute has left 8,000 utility workers locked out of their jobs for more than two weeks.

headline.seo: Pressure Rises on Con Edison and Union to End Dispute
headline.main: Pressure Rises on Con Ed and Union to End Dispute
headline.print_headline: Pressure Rises on Con Ed and Union to Resolve Dispute

docs.abstract: Pressure is rising on Con Edison and its biggest union, the Utility Workers Union of America, to resolve a contract dispute that has left 8,000 utility workers locked out of their jobs for more than two weeks, as New York City continues to be hit by heat waves; representatives for both sides meet again but fail to reach an agreement.
docs.snippet: Representatives of the two sides met again on Saturday but failed to reach an agreement. The dispute has left 8,000 utility workers locked out of their jobs for more than two weeks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several of the city’s most strained institutions are partially or completely uninsured, state records show, lacking what is seen as a standard safeguard across the country.

headline.seo: Some Hospitals in New York Lack a Malpractice Safety Net
headline.main: Troubled New York Hospitals Forgo Coverage for Malpractice
headline.print_headline: Some Hospitals in New York Lack a Malpractice Safety Net

docs.abstract: Several New York City hospitals are partially or completely uninsured for malpractice, forgoing what is considered a standard safeguard across the country; executives of these hospitals, most of which are in poor neighborhoods, say their dire financial circumstances and high malpractice premiums make it impractical to pay millions of dollars a year for insurance; insurance experts say decision to do without malpractice coverage is shortsighted.
docs.snippet: Several of the city’s most strained institutions are partially or completely uninsured, state records show, lacking what is seen as a standard safeguard across the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: The new health care law calls for expansion of Medicaid, but American voters may well rebel against the program over time.

headline.seo: Medicaid’s New Tug of War – Economic View
headline.main: The New Tug of War Over Medicaid
headline.print_headline: The New Tug of War Over Medicaid

docs.abstract: Tyler Cowen Economic View column predicts that American voters may rebel against the health care law, especially the Medicaid expansion, over time; points out the basic dynamic is that state and federal government have opposite incentives as to how many people should be kept in Medicaid; suggests that government-subsidized and mandated catastrophic insurance and a freer market for other expenditures might present a more attractive alternative.
docs.snippet: The new health care law calls for expansion of Medicaid, but American voters may well rebel against the program over time.

docs.lead_paragraph: Although initial reactions to the Supreme Court’s ruling that Medicaid expansion was up to individual states was along party lines, subsequent responses are more nuanced.

headline.seo: Governors Face Hard Choices Over Medicaid Expansion
headline.main: Many Governors Are Still Unsure About Medicaid Expansion
headline.print_headline: Many Governors Are Still Unsure About Medicaid Expansion

docs.abstract: Initial reactions by governors to the Supreme Court’s ruling that Medicaid expansion is up to individual states are split along party lines, but subsequent responses are more nuanced; most governors in both parties at the National Governors Association meeting say they are unsure and need to study how to proceed with their Medicaid programs.
docs.snippet: Although initial reactions to the Supreme Court’s ruling that Medicaid expansion was up to individual states was along party lines, subsequent responses are more nuanced.

docs.lead_paragraph: From apps to underwear, logistical masters of Silicon Valley have turned traveling into an art form. Here’s how they do it.

headline.seo: How the Tough Get Going: Silicon Valley Travel Tips
headline.main: How the Tough Get Going: Silicon Valley Travel Tips

docs.abstract: Frequent-flying entrepreneurs of Silicon Valley have turned traveling into an art form; several travel aces from some of the Valley's best-known companies share their tips and tricks for streamlined adventure.
docs.snippet: From apps to underwear, logistical masters of Silicon Valley have turned traveling into an art form. Here’s how they do it.
